comment:
Color - copper brown. A quick swirl shows sparse legs in the glass

Nose - maple syrup, vanilla, varnished oak

Palate - maple, caramel and baking spices, with a fairly rich mouthfeel for the proof.

Finish - pretty quick, some lingering spice but more subdued than I usually get from OF

A few drops of water muted the maple/oak  on the nose but brought out a hint of dark stone fruit and more vanilla.  On the palate, the water brought out more sweetness, with the caramel coming to the front and lingering a bit on the finish.  I liked this both ways, although I think the nose was better neat.

I'm not really a huge OF fan. I like Statesmen and 1920 OK, but not nearly as much as other brands. To me this 1910 is a bit darker/richer, with the spice softened a bit compared to other OF expressions. For  me that's a good thing. People who love 1920 probably won't like it as much due to its lower proof and lacking that bright/spicy character.

Nose (3.75):  Brown sugar and plums.  Slightly ethanol for proof but dissipated quickly.  Sweeter than the 1920.

Palate (4.5):  Burnt brown sugar, raisins with some carmel and vanilla underlying.  Very good sipping neat might not hold up as well in mixed drink.  

Finish (3.75):  Plumbs and sugar and then the heat comes in.  Kind of cinnampn-apple.  Finish is quicker with good aftertaste.  Higher proof may have sustained finish but all in all petty pleasing.

If you like Statesman this has similar profile with nicer nose and a bit richer.  I like it dead even with the 1920.
I WISH it was higher proof, but it is good juice. Not up to snuff of 1920, but definitely has a unique richness; raisins, plum, and toasted marshmallow. Pleasant nose.
Lots of caramel and maple flavor. But a very smooth bourbon.
As the glass warms, notes of raisin bread, white cake, frosting, caramel burst out of the glass. The palate is full & oily, finishing with flavors of caramel, nuts & fruitcake.
Sweet, burnt sugar, vanilla, soft mouthfeel, sweet aftertaste

True to it’s name.
Banana, Maple and Brown sugar sweet. Very lite on the spice.
Makes me think of Bananas Foster.
Wow !!! Winner !!! Sweet, oaky and delicious. OF does it again. At 93 proof, it’s very drinkable. Maybe too....

Nose: Maple, vanilla, caramel and cedar
Taste: Smooth butterscotch, raisin.

Finish: sweet to spicy, not too dry

Almost bought after tour last Thursday, found at Total Wine and More for $13 cheaper. Great find.

Deep ruddy brown color. Char, banana bread, baking spice, toasted marshmallow, pound cake, vanilla pudding, warm caramel, slightly floral, just a hint of dill in the background. Very rich and full bodied
Chocolate roman candy toffee, vanilla, dried figs, hot caramel
salty and caramel. not as complex as 1920, not quite as good either. still a decent addition to my collection.

Grabbed a bottle from the distillery this week on a trip through KY. Big fan of 1920, so I was eager to see how it stacks up. Lots of indistinct baked-good flavors to pick over. I keep coming back to Irish soda bread (raisins!). It's not all dessert though, there are ripples of that heavily charred oak which I'm guessing will be a turn off for some, and probably also why they dialed back the proof. All in all it's its own thing, and worth the price of admission.

The nose is sweet and boozy with some apricot and banana maybe a hint of ginger

The sweetness continues with a rich mouthfeel with bananas and cream

Finish is short but smooth with a little heat and oak and cinnamon 

Enjoyable dessert bourbon if not overly complex
Very good.  Oaky. Fruity and sweet.
Very sweet, some banana in the palate. Definite oak as well.
Rock solid.  Bursting with flavor and spice more typical of a higher proof whiskey.  Somehow they pull it off in this 93 proof gem.  Amazing mouthfeel that is quite viscous.
Has a sweet nose. Leather and tobacco upfront on the pallette. Finish is sweet butterscotch and toffee.
Not a heavy nose. Taste has a small hint of oak and cherry. Much simpler then the 1920.
@ TWCP Tasting Bar; very fun, unique bourbon.  The second barreling does a lot for this...rich, sweet, smokey.  Looks and drinks above the 93 proof

Lots of cherry on the nose and palate. The deep charred oak contrasts very well with the cherry candy cough drop notes on the palate. This is an excellent bourbon, and my favorite of the Old Forester Whiskey Row series.
tastes rich and dark. delighfuly smooth.
The second time I drank this got a sour note on the nose that I just couldn’t get over.  Palate is sweet and finish is oaky and medium.  I enjoyed the drink other than the weird nose I couldn’t place
I quess I don't get out much, but I really like this one 😋

Merry Christmas to me!🎄 Got this as a gift. This is exactly as the notes describe, and to me, delicious. Wow, very good. 
I am starting to believe there is a bourbon conspiracy against Old Forester, because this IS NOT an 82. NF’nW! Love it. I hope PA gets it soon.

Very smooth bourbon, and very sweet.  give this to any of your friends that say they aren't whiskey drinkers. 

I actually like to "blend" this with the 1920 and the statesman. it kind of creates a "poor man's Birthday Bourbon."
I don’t care if this is forced or not. Freaking delicious! The 1920 was my favorite in the line up until I tried this. 82? Compared to what?

Chocolate, oak, hazelnut.
Finish is very long with dominant hazelnut note.

Smell is amazing.  A less oaky version of Woodford double oaked which is one of my other favorites. More fruit and altogether just intoxicating as a smell can be. 

The palate doesn’t let you down. Sweet but not overly.  Oaky but just enough.  Smooth.  

Finish. Enough of a finish to keep you around which is saying something for a “lowish” 93 proof.

Altogether amazing.  Immediately one of my favorites.

Best of the Old Forester/Woodford offerings. Vanilla, honey, butterscotch and sweet oak on the nose. A little spice and brown sugar on the palate, and for a non-wheated bourbon it’s sweet and smooth on the finish. If Weller 12 and Woodford double oaked had a baby, this is it.
So smooth it's hard to believe it has alcohol. Very dark. Sweet flavor of dates and rich caramel.

Nose - Dark chocolate and cherries

Palate - Smooth with chocolate up front, fruity finish

Don’t know why this scored so low from the expert, it should at least be a 90. Great sip if you can find it MSRP
chocolate, caramel, vanilla, heavy oak and butterscotch. cherry. fruity and spicy. full and rich.
Amazing toasted vanilla nose, deep charr. Lots of flavors. Very impressed.
Really good. I'd put next to E.C. BP. Might be my new favorite.
Strong nose, classic notes. Balanced on the palate, with spice and a nice sweet note towards the end. Fruit. Leather. Baking spice. Chocolate. Fine sipping whiskey. 1/5/19
Sweet, rich start and spicy, “cigar” finish

nose:
I get strong hints of leather, oak, cherry, and tobacco
with the Carmel and vanilla being faint in the background.

pallet: up front you can get that oak and corn immediately but the finish is very delicious has strong dark chocolate, with sweet fruits drizzled with vanilla, Carmel, and a hint of butterscotch.

Nose - Fresh graham cracker crust, cinnamon, vanilla, banana, oatmeal raisin cookies 
Palate - rich and sweet, with oily mouthfeel with lingering notes of baking spices - cinnamon and nutmeg
Finish - smooth, like water. Lingering baking spice notes give way to its original sweetness. 

Love. This. Bourbon!!!
I’m in the minority here but I love this stuff. Vanilla, marshmallow, deep caramel.

Nose: one of the best noses in bourbon. Sweet oak, raisins and other dark fruits. 

Palate: spicy fruit but a little tart... some smoky-ness like from a bbq- joint. 

Finish: sweet cola, citrus, quick finish. Slight rye kick but quite smooth

Verdict:  A unique and incredible bourbon.  Overwhelmingly sweet while also wholly defined by pervasive and astringent barrel char.  Jekyll and Hyde.  Underwhelming nose.  Definitely a "must try" but won't be for everybody.  A tad pricey.
 
A dark, rich amber.  Oily with slow legs.  Spiced cherry, vanillin, unripened fruit, and a gentle but persistent wood char on the nose.  Burnt sugar and cream with a subdued mint and some medicinal notes.  Complex, but not quite alluring.  The sweetness requires teasing out from behind the stronger, semi-acrid scents.
 
Where the nose earns mixed reviews, the palate wows with sweetness.  An immediate rush of toffee and sweetened black tea.  Creme brulee.  Blackened mashmallow.  Caramel swirled with cinnamon.  The rush of sweet fades slowly into very strong barrel notes, somewhat bitter with char and cinnamon candy spice.  The drying astringency lasts forever on the finish, hardly fading before the next taste.

Bronze color. Brown sugar, stone fruit, and some smoke aroma. Brown sugar, stone fruits, and some tropical fruit notes with charcoal underneath. More charcoal and brown sugar in the somewhat short finish.

Excellent round flavor. 


Not hot.  Smooth.  Plenty of oak
Not bad. Wouldn't be a regular drinker for me, but smooth and had a fruity like sweetness to it. Reminded me of angel's envy but less of the port
Sweet caramel, honey and vanilla.  Very little burn.  Nice flavor.
Charred Oak Syrup. Still can’t decide if I like this one or not after finishing a bottle. Will try with a Cigar when the weather breaks.  Recommend you try this one before you buy given the price.

The nose is crazy in this. Hint of that maple sweetness like woodford DO but I also get a strong bbq sauce note. Odd. Taste follows heavy on the maple with sweet char tones and smoke. Tastes this once a week for a month and get a bit of a different experience each time. I enjoy this a lot, a more well balanced woodford DO. 1920 is still king though.

Everything tastes charred and it’s wonderful. Reminds me of woodford double oak which is a really good thing. Burnt caramel into charred oak on the finish. Small after sizzle that reminds you it’s still there. Big fan, top two in the whiskey row series with 1920.

Nose: banana, oak, leather

Palate: honey barbecue, toasted wood, baking spices 

Finish: medium with spicy cola notes, warmth

People are right to talk about cigars/tobacco with this one...

Trouble is I don’t smoke.

1 star for good mouthfeel/consistency and color.
Toasted Marshmallows, caramel, chocolate, burnt wood.

This whiskey has tons of flavor.  The nose is unique and very inviting.  The palate is a bit of a mixed bag.  At first it’s sweet, then the oaky-char really sets in. Smokey flavor takes over, which is nice at first but the smoke really dominates.  There’s no big finish which is a little disappointing considering how interestingly this bourbon starts out. 

I bought this for $48 at a big liquor store. It’s worth it to me at that price because I find it a unique arrow in the flavor quiver.  However, I don’t consider this a super-frequent sipper because the smoke is so dominant.

If you’re a collector like me, throw it on the bar. You’ll like having it to dip into!
Oh my woody goodness. Extra vanilla, oak and barrel char, some fruity notes along with “sweet” leather, cocoa. Gives WRDO a run for the money for sure.

Very unique, almost a bourbon with a splash of scotch. I need another dram to give a good description but smoke and cacao were up front and ultra ripe green banana to the end. Nice and oily, delicious and a decent finish that last but isn’t too hot.
Cocoa powder, whipped cream, chocolate ganache, fudge brownies, cinnamon, velvety smooth, tobacco, long finish, caramel, banana
nose was great, caramel corn, vanilla custard and oak. taste was muted of those flavors with minimal heat.
Very rich. Char, oak, grape. Honey sweetness. Much sweeter than Woodford Double Oak. Hot. It's good but I prefer Old Forester 1920.
I love this stuff. It reminds me a lot of Woodford Reserve Double Oaked. It has that same sweet taste that I really enjoy in a bourbon.
Honey and vanilla on the nose. Sweet and rich at first taste, then some low heat. Easy finish with a slight oak and coffee aftertaste.

Nose: banana, dark fruits, bbq sauce

Palate: very rich, toffee, and it’s decently spicy, with toasted oak

Finish: balanced and medium

Reminds me a little bit of Bakers. A sweeter and softer OF 1920

for me it pulled too much char and oak from being double barreled.   having said that i feel that most people who are new to shopping bourbon best will find this very approachable.  if that's you give it a try!
Brown sugar salted caramel apple. Awesome
Crazy good. Very sweet nose.  Just fits my palate. Well balanced, ton of vanilla and caramel on the palate. Slight oak on the finish. If you like Makers 46, this is better.
Beautiful nose of caramel, toffee, honey, and maybe a slight candied cherry. Very sweet on the nose. Dark, rich flavors on the palate finishing with a very well balanced dry oak.
Raisins and caramel on the nose and taste. Long smooth finish

Eyes: very dark (think Pikesville rye kind of dark)
Nose: straight away you get molasses, vanilla, cinnamon and dry red wine( not like a musk on a finished bourbon but more like a glass of really dry red wine)
Palate: starts off super sweet and keeps going. Milk chocolate, root beer, and ends with a strong brown sugar that lingers on the lips. 
Finish: it ends sweet and dry. The dryness is most likely a  byproduct of the second heavily charred barrel the whiskey is finished in.
Mouth feel: thin but thats to be expected from a 93 proof
Overall: very good pour. You will love it if you are a fan of the sweeter bourbon
On reflection and comparison to Russell’s its a bit sweet and week. No need to buy again
Smooth woody, well rounded, full mouth flavor.

Glass: dark amber, deep & inviting
Nose: rolling notes between light fruit, vanilla and definite char & Oak
Palate: seems richer than 1870 but shy of 1897. The light fruit and sugars are evident but it is the woody notes that stand out. Finish: shorter yet satisfying 
Great whiskey.

Nose: caramelized sugar
Taste: sweet, low burn, slightly viscous
Finish: smooth, warming, hangs around for a few seconds.
While I prefer 1920, this is a complex and unique bourbon with a distinctive smoky finish.

Nose - Dark chocolate, leather, dark toffee, light cinnamon

Taste - Sweet toffee, very drying initial mouthfeel, sweet oak, chocolate, brown simple syrup, hint of sweet leather, maple syrup, espresso crema

Finish - Sweet toffee, sweet mocha, tiny bit of heat/tingle, maple syrup, leather

Score - 86/100

Final Thoughts - I quite liked this one as it hit on at least 2 or 3 of things I like together which is chocolate, coffee, & maple syrup. This is definitely on the sweeter end of the spectrum, very similar to Woodford Reserve Double Oaked and I would treat this as more of a dessert dram than a daily drinking dram. Nice chocolate & gentle coffee/mocha notes throughout. Doesn't really drink like the proof and is overall quite tasty.

Would I drink it if offered? - Yes

Would I specifically order it? - Yes

Would I buy a bottle? - Yes if it's around the same price as Woodford Reserve Double Oaked

This is a superb drink, with one of the chewier, thicker mouthfeels I've been able to find.

The initial burst is vanilla toffee or rich caramel. Oaky and lightly sweet underneath. There is a cinnabon (cinnamon roll/ bun) quality to this that really captures both the richness of cream cheese frosting and pastry all at once. 

UPON REVISITING
I am revisiting this some weeks later, after the bottle has had a chance to open up some.  My initial quality rating remains unchanged, but the flavor nuances are different.  This is much softer and more mellow than I remember, still rich, with a soft cocoa with marshmallow foam quality to it.
Dark in color, almost an auburn, or burnt brown. Smells raisin sweet, and tastes very smooth with cherry and vanilla notes, but has a tart aftertaste I’m not crazy about.
So many cherries, some vanilla, and hardly any burn. Reminds me a lot of EH Taylor SiB. Very rich too. Not much of a finish though.
Oak, vanilla, toasted marshmallow, brown sugar. Covers the pallet with oil and you can tell that the oak is there. Pretty smooth and long finish but has that sugar oak taste that lingers

Nose: Super sweet on the nose. Cake batter, vanilla frosting and sugar cookies. 

Taste: Sweetness carries over. Again, cake batter, frosting, a touch of oak all held together by an oily viscosity.
Oaky, smooth.  Very similar to Woodford Double Oaked.
Brown sugar and banana bread and char > char and more bananas. Simple finish. Enjoying this more after being open a week.

Nose of sweet caramel and brown sugar nicely balanced with wood and char. More brown sugar and a hint of citrus on the palate. VERY rich! If you love a rich bourbon, this is for you. Mid-length finish with a mild oaky astringency. So satisfying.

Nose: orange peel, vanilla
Palate: walnut, cinnamon. Marzipan finish.
Taste like that one time I got my beer I was drinking mixed up with the empty can I was spitting my dip into.

Neat.  Amazing nose.  Oak.  Vanilla.  Cherry.  Pepper.  Baking spice.  Initial taste did not hit me right.  I’m going to let it sit and clear my palate.  It was all ethanol and grass.  Little toasted marshmallow on the end.

Going back a few minutes later.  A delicious toasted marshmallow on the nose now too.   Reminds me of a Woodford Double Oak the more it opens up.

Thin, watery texture.  Brown sugary initially.  Cherry and berries.  Vanilla. Wood flavors.  Bitter, burnt coffee.

First pour disappointed.  I had this at a restaurant and thought it was great, this may just need to open up.  1920 is better thus far.
Ross Morrow Ice Challenge. Dark amber color, wood on the nose and a rich sweet initial taste. Doesn’t finish hot, would definitely add a bottle to the collection

So after having the 1920 after it being talked up, and then not getting what the fuss is about, I thought I would try the 1910, which is nowhere to be found. Happen to see it for a little higher than normal in Times Square NYC (to be expected) so I thought I’d give it a try.

The nose is sweet with vanilla, and brown sugar dominating. A slight leathery note pokes through.
The palate is sweet with a follow through from the nose, but added leather and very oaky. 
The finish has a slight bitterness and a little ethanol. But I would consider this a longer finish.
I really enjoyed this one. Definitely reminds me of the Woodford Double Oaked, which makes sense, since this one was also put into a second charred oak barrel.
I need to do a side-by-side comparison with 1910 and 1920 and then one between 1910 and Woodford DO.
Butterscotch all the way, and not in an overpowering way. Would buy a bottle for sure
Wow. Can’t wait to get this again. Very tasty. Has a nice creamy mouth fill and a delicious Kentucky hug.
Rich vanilla toffee/caramel nose and palette. Very smooth.

This is good, typical OF profile.  Would describe as a lower proof(-20) than the 1920.   For those that like higher proof would think you would prefer 1920, if not will prob prefer this.  Both are great to me, would rate higher but prefer the higher proof and this is much harder to find.

Nose: sweet vanilla, toffee, salty caramel, hint of citrus, maybe orange peel, faint rye over time. 
Body: medium-medium long
Palate: little juicy fruit on the start, black pepper, Little smokier over time. 
Finish: pretty long and warming. Fruity
Note: this is good. Not amazing. The bubble gum fruitiness of this surprised me. 
After multiple drinks this one has really grown on me. The bubblicious sweetness is really good and I’m upgrading this to really good 4 stars.

this was my first old forester and it was different as a bourbon.  toasted marshmallow and pecan, then cherry flavor with liquid smoke that made it taste like medicinal cherry.  if you like that then it's wonderful.  i look forward to tasting the more widely loved 1920
Vanilla with a medium spice on the backend

Nose: holy green apple Batman. That's all I get tho

Taste:mellow flavor with apple and spice and Carmel.

Finish: leads into a long candy finish.
Complex flavor profile but an overwhelming profile of banana. Not a fan.  Finish is short and uneventful.
Vanilla & cherry pie. Has become one of my favorites. A great after dinner pour.

The nose on this is a pretty complex array; campfire smoke, charcoal, leather, molasses, cola, overripe black cherry, banana, and mahogany wood.

These aromas are all present in the palate, with the addition of creme brûlée, milk chocolate, and nougat. The finish is where this really excels with notes of cashew nut, barrel spices, black cherry cola, oak, and toasted marshmallow. You do wish for it to go a little longer as it’s merely medium length. Mouthfeel on the lighter side. 

A delightful whiskey. But...(yes there’s a but) it does suffer a bit from a lack of punch due the lower proof. I would KILL for this at 107-110 proof. As it is, it’s a great dessert whiskey and worth the $58 price point anytime.

What it is:
Very warm with a smoky nose.  Very spicy and smoky on the pallet with dried savory fruits ( figs, currants).  Creamy with a thick mouth feel.  Ethonol heavy finish with a lingering smoke after taste.  Very smooth and easy, with interesting flavors all the way.

What it isn't:
Sweet.
Floral
Like any Old Forester I have ever had.(I generally love OF bottles)
Easy to find.
Worthy of all the hype and demand (IMO).
My favorite of the Whiskey Row series.

This pour is good, but leaves me wondering why the much better OF 1920 is on shelves and readily available, and this is almost at unicorn status???

It's worth trying, buying, savoring, and sharing...but not chasing.  There are many $55 bottles that I prefer.
I thought it was delicious. Nice spice up front with a smooth finish from what I contribute to the high amount of malted barley

Nose is underripe bananas, sweet oak, light cinnamon and a slight punch of alcohol sting.

Palate is creamy banana pudding, walnuts, chocolate, and some astringency. 

The finish makes you really wish it was longer. It is creamy with a lingering vanilla, but it quickly evaporates and leaves a dry oaky cinnamon behind.

I like this a lot, but for the price and because it feels higher proof I would recommend the 1920 or the 100 proof.
Unique flavor with minimum spice. Very easy drinker and one of my favorite that I have picked up. Was hesitant due to the bottle I got being the re-release, but glad I decided to take it home!

This is a good example of a Bourbon that you need some time with to really figure out how one feels about it! I am about half way thru a bottle and feel that it's finally hit it's stride. Before we jump into the notes let's review what's in the bottle:

Mash Bill: 72% Corn, 18% Rye, 10% Malted Barley
Cask: New Charred oak and finished in heavily charred oak barrels
Age: 4+ Years
ABV: 46.5%

Let's dive into the tasting:

It's a very rich entry with dark red fruits, rich syrup, spice and some tannic oak. Nuts and vanilla on the mid palette with a medium oak and red fruit driven finish that's a bitt astringent. 

So my main issue was initially it was a bit too rich and astringent for me. Not fully balanced and honestly I felt it was overrated. As I have spent time with the bottle it's mellowed a bit and now I feel it's an enjoyable occasional after dinner dram. For the price point I would probably re buy it but for me it's not a must have. 

Cheers all!

I had this at a bar a while back and have been hunting with no luck for a while. Finally grabbed a bottle. 

1910 is a double oaked whisky which gives it a bit more of a chocolate, savory, creme brulee thing and it seems to do this often. Woodford double oaked being the gold standard of this. Though my all time favorite bourbon was the jefferson 16 year double oaked (12 years then 4 years). That is one I wish I could have found a second bottle. Anyway comes in at 46.5% which is a bit light for bourbon and then oddly uses this "Old Fine Whisky" statement and then on the neck it tells us something about being the first bottled in bond (of course this isn't bottled in bond). OK so Old Forester is the worst company of respected bourbon makers when it comes to marketing. I'm not joking, had I not been told about this, I'd have never bought this with how bad this marketing really is.

Nose - This is sweet. I get dusty old leather, over ripe almost rotting apple, some orchard spice, maybe even some old books, and just a never ending sweet vanilla that's shining all the way through.

Taste - my first though it watered down woodford double oaked. I get a creamy note that really opens the whole whisky up. It's like a bourbon cream flavor in a bourbon vs the other way around. It seems to be almost a vanilla forward oak cream if that makes any sense. Some dusty leather and wood. The finish gives me creme brulee elements that burnt vanilla. 

Just a quick note on this - this is a sipper for SMALL pours. Too much and the sweetness over powers and it starts to get off putting. I don't get that same issue with woodford double oaked so perhaps this is sweeter or more heavy in flavor. I'm not sure why but I had a large pour last night and I was debating blending or just capping it for tomorrow. That shouldn't stop anyone from buying this in bulk if they can. It's outstanding bourbon and one I hope to never be without. 

A rare 3.5 star rating on a bourbon that retails for about 50 bucks. I'm debating a 4 but the mouth feel is too thin for that.
Smokey bourbon. Smell of nutmeg cinnamon and smoke. No sweetness. Nutty up front with smoke throughout. A hint of creamy vanilla on end

N: vanilla, Dr Pepper, bananas, maple syrup, 
P: Mexican vanilla, char, oak, thin
F: short, burnt oak, Coca Cola

The nose is very sweet and playful. I pick up vanilla, butter scotch, and something like raspberries are good old fashion red Kool-Aid. If I sniff on I feel like I detect just a bit of oak as well as a warm pipe smoke aroma like black Cavendish. I don’t get a lot of spice. Others have said toasted marshmallow which I can see that I don’t think you’ll be my first guess.

The precipitous moved on the pallet and I feel like raspberries and caramel come through. There’s a bit of baking spice to it but it doesn’t seem to predominate. In a lot of ways he reminds me of a softer version of old Forrester 1920 and it’s complex but just without the heat and spice of its higher proof brother.  I think the only thing lacking would be just a little bit more smoke or char. Otherwise this is excellent.

Second only to 1920

Sweet then complex. Wonderful finish.
Really fantastic. A surprising amount of heat given the proof, but it fades away as richness and sweetness take over.
Nice char, light smoke, dry bourbon.

Nose: Sherry and caramel. Maybe a bit of lingering butterscotch?

Palate: Full body, very creamy. Oak, caramel, and some chocolate covered cherry. 

Finish: Easy brown sugar and caramel, then some hot cinnamon that sticks around a while.
Not fantastic on the nose, smoky and even slightly astringent. Better on the palate, notes of chocolate, marshmallow, oak. Sweet without fruit. Long oak finish.

Nose: cherry cheese cake and dark vanilla and oak

Palate: Dark cherries, almost medicinal. Dark oak

Finish: cherries on the front with lots of dry oak. Finish goes on for a long time.
Absolute flavor bomb! Basically an amped up version of the 1870 for me.
Really enjoyed this bottle. Hints of Carmel and toffee on nose. Smooth drinker with easy heat. Pick up in the Carmel, vanilla, cinnamon and chocolate. Great dram on a cold winter night!

Beautiful deep bronze color. 
Nose- smoke/char brown sugar slight caramel
Palate- marshmallow light smoke
Finish- long finish with lingering sweetness
Overall- very pleasant and enjoyable, one I would definitely sip as a regular
Only been searching for about a year..didn’t disappoint. Smooth, better with an ice ball.

Just re-tasted this.   I like it more than I remembered.  Took a sip of Jack Daniels to attempt to reset expectations to some kind of standard from the “allocated” bourbons I’ve been trying and then tried this again.  Really nice!  And easy to find at the store.

Love this one.  I am new to bourbon and tried this at the distillery.  Regret not getting a bottle.  A dear friend remembered this and got me one for a special occasion back home and its delicious!  Truly special and memorable!
Unsweetened chocolate, vanilla, oak, tobacco, raisin.

My favorite in the OF whiskey row series. Unlike the 1920 I do not add water to the 1910. This one is double oaked and that attracts me.. the nose is oak and sweet. I get the wood and caramel. The taste is oak first, cherries and some spice. The finish is oak lingering of course with some vanilla.
Lots of wood. Some vanilla. cinnamon on the finish
Very dark, rich and full bodied. Smokey and sweet initially, with minimal spice and a heavily wood and oakey lingering finish. One of the most oakey bourbons for the price, and an easy sipper!

Deep flavor, smooth. Very good.


*Tasted at J Boyd's
Slightly less sweet ice cream sundae

This year for the holidays I’m going to try a brand new whiskey every day in December. #lifegoals

Dec. 30

I tried to make today’s entry for Jim Beam Peach. As I was attempting to create the spirit, Distiller crashed. I tried a few times after, and the system couldn’t or wouldn’t process it. I’m going to take that as a sign that I shouldn’t submit the review. Pretty sure I compared it to goat sacrifice at some point. Probably for the best.

Anyway, this is a bourbon I’ve been looking forward to for some time. Used to be super hard to find in my region, no longer is. I’ve never had any Old Forrester products, so I’m excited about that too! If this is good, I’ll have to dip more into the other numbers. Let’s see how fine this little guy really is.

Nose reminds me heavily of Booker’s, and I mean that as a compliment. There’s oak, vanilla, honey. There’s a little something extra there that I can’t place, but I’m pretty sure it’ll be a flavor on the body and then make sense to my nose.

Holy cow this body. So that scent on the nose was strawberries, because that is on this body, and detecting that as a whiskey note is a personal first for me. I love it when that happens. Other flavors include honey, cane sugar, and possibly watermelon, but that strawberry really takes the show. That is fascinating.

After a rockstar nose and body, the finish is a bit of a let down. A bitterness enters that knocks you back to reality after a really sweet body. There is a bit of an aftertaste that reminds me of something from Elijah Craig—something that quite frankly turned me off from the product line for over a year now. Black licorice maybe? Even if it’s a letdown, I’ll allow it. That body is so good and unique to anything I’ve ever had on a bourbon, that I’ll suffer through some nasty ass black jellybeans at the end. This tastes like a cousin of Hotel Tango Bravo. I wouldn’t be surprised if they had similar mash bills and yeast strains, and if you’re a fan of one, you should try the other. I’ll have to have them back to back one day, but from memory, I think I slightly prefer Hotel Tango. That licorice or whatever is potent.

‘Tis the season. I DO have 1 more new whiskey lined up. Thanks St. Nick!
Nose is Carmel and créame brulee and smoky. Taste is more smoky burnt sugar and plenty of oak. Not much heat at all. It’s warm going down but nowhere does it hit you hard.

Weirdly smelled Fruit Stripes Gum (wut), gummy candy, sugar, oranges, and peach yogurt (yes). 

A little bit more spice on the taste. The fruit is there, though, not at the forefront. Vanilla pound cake pokes its caloric head up to say hello. Lingers a bit on the finish. 

This was cool.
Wet wood and light vanilla on the nose for me. I didn’t get much of a banana scent but it did show up noticeably on the finish but gave way to a nutty taste as it sat on ice.
Brown sugar with hint of vanilla and pepper

Cherry Bomb. 
 Goes down smooth and lingers a bit but, not as long as an unwelcomed guest.
Would be an excellent $30-35 bottle (paid $60).
Enjoyed it all the same.
Yum yum in the tum tum

Not seeing the hype on 1910 or 1920,to me they are just overpriced mediocre bourbons. For being only 93 proof it's very spicy with a sharp finish. To me, 1910 is just ok, there are many bourbons out there I'd rather have for less money. ($55)
Great bourbon, dark caramel color, syrupy smooth, bananas, with a honey finish
Neat. Nose is sweet caramel molasses. Taste is sweet and spiced up front with a spicy oak finish. I like it.

Color: rust

Aroma: malty sweetness and yeast.

Taste: initial hit is oily and coats the mouth but isn’t overly flavorful. Then it builds, vanilla pod and unsweetened cookie dough, then boom! cinnamon coffee cake.

Finish: the finish is everything with this pour since the front end makes you feel a little cheated. You get EVERYTHING on the back end and it’s delicious, spicy, sweet, and flavorful.

Where 1920 is balanced spicy sweetness overall, 1910 hits big on the back end, and without the burn of big finishes.

Smooth factor: A-
Some cherry and chocolate, very good.

Old foresters attempt at double oak. Neat backstory (#1) too bad there isn't one so which one is real? Was there a fire on the bottling line and the whiskey had to be held in a second set of new char oak until it could be bottled? or Did Brown of Brown-Forman simply want darker, richer, ultra aged barrels of the best Old Forester had to offer? John Fitzgerald rip off (the $2K 350ml one). This one is not as good to me as the 1920 or the lower floor single barrel store picks that ironically taste like sweeter better versions of 1910.  Nose is classic bourbon. Caramel, vanilla, brown sugar, oak, cherry, sweetness in the back. Taste is Oak, brown sugar sweetness, maraschino cherry, mid palate the rye spice and a tobacco note roll in and set up camp through the finish along with that double oak quality. The totality of the finish is I'd say medium. For almost the same price I'd pick up the 1920 and for $10 less I'd grab a store pick if you can. It's better than average but it's an elijah craig profile and flavors with extra oak. 3.75 bourbon if this was $35-40
Maple syrup and waffles, banana foster, creme brûlée, Saigon cinnamon

Agree with others that the start is a bit underwhelming and the finish is long and strong. Wasn’t wild about it at first, but improved as I sipped and the whisky rock melted. Glad I tried it, but don’t know that I’ll rush to buy a second bottle.
Very sweet. Good with slight notes of Carmel and vanilla

Nose: vanilla cake, slight caramel
Taste: sweet, fruity and oaky
Nose of strong bananas foster. Medium sweet, burnt white sugar flavor. Smooth, medium length, mildly sweet finish. Very interesting neat.

-On the nose: let this breath for a few minutes and you will find a delicious bananas foster with cherries on top waiting for you. It is exactly that and it is intoxicating. I spent way too much time with my nose in the glass before actually tasting this. 

-Palette and Finish: very smooth and light. A little sweetness carried through from the bananas and vanilla ice cream greet you with cinnamon that carries you into the finish. I had hoped for a more bold flavor, but at this proof I’m not surprised at how light it truly is on the palette. However, the finish lasts pretty long and even though the lower proof makes for a lack of boldness, this long finish has such a delightful flavor of cinnamon and barrel spices. 

The proof is lower and doesn’t bring much heat or boldness, but the flavor profiles are pleasant and long lasting. 
I would say that drinking this without getting the scent profile would be a missed opportunity to add a necessary part of enjoying this bourbon.
Deep caramel, charred oak, and rich with a long smooth finish.  One of my favorites. The professional review needs to be readdressed on this Whiskey. It’s great

Check out my video review here: 

https://youtu.be/Vj6AN_B9wUA


.

Lots of banana on the nose, butterscotch, oak and Carmel on the palate, the Banana comes through as well.  I like this a lot, the 1920 probably beats it, but when u want something a little lower proof this is a great stand in.
Very enjoyable! Aroma of maple syrup and bananas, sweet and smooth in the mouth. Only complaint is the really short finish, but it’s an easy sipper
Mint, cherries, brown sugar on the nose. Sweet caramelized bananas foster up front. Smooth nutty, peppery finish with a lingering cherry syrup flavor.
Heavy wood, sweet with green bananas. More wood in the taste with heavy char.
One of my favorite bourbons. Rick and spicy.

Vanilla icing on the nose, and slighting spicy. This is reminiscent of the Woodford Double Oaked, but not as rich and milder on the finish. The spirit disappears instantly when swallowed. Easy drinking, and very obviously double oaked. Wood spice with caramel and velvety vanilla, plus a little fresh menthol, are what I get.

The nose is so clearly green bananas it’s humorous. Followed by a sweet vanilla pipe tobacco smoke. 

The palate initially is light, with praline, vanilla and a nuttiness along with some of that banana coming thru. Reminiscent to a bananas foster. I agree that the oakiness is a bit harsh and feels rushed due to the second aging process, making me crave a smoother finish. All around a good bourbon to be sip’t neat or in an old fashion (done right)

This is easily dessert in a glass: palate is chocolate cake and coffee.  Oily mouthfeel with sourdough bread as a background note.  The trip finishes up with cherry and oak.  

This is quite similar to another double casked bourbon: the Woodford Reserve Double Oaked.  Both are stand outs from the status quo.  (And interestingly enough, both have Brown-Forman as the parent company.)



My Rating Glossary:  

Two Stars:           "I'd rather be drinking lite beer."
Two 1/2 Stars:    "Posh rubbish."
Three Stars:        "I love whisk(e)y.  This is average love."
Three 1/2 Stars: "May buy again."
Four Stars:          "I've got to get you into my life."
Four 1/2 Stars:   "Better than drugs."
Five Stars:           "Life is good.  Whisky makes it better."
Dark Fruit, Sweet, Maple Syrup, Raisins, Vanilla, Carmel
Bananas and smoke were the first smells that hit me. A relatively mild taste with a spicier finish makes this a pretty good bourbon.
Beautiful dark color. Rich in flavor; dark cherry, chocolate, spices reminiscent of star anise and clove. Smooth. Long buttery finish
My tasting notes on 1910. Noses charred vanilla and green banana. Almost cherry but definitely fruited. Sips strong/bold for 93 proof. Spicy. Fruited vanilla notes burnt wood and spicy.
Cola/Root Beer, bubble gum, bananas, light tobacco nose. I get a bit of toasted marshmallows on the palate with more bananas. It's interesting but I prefer the 1920 hands down.
Cherry, vanilla, heavy cream, under-ripe strawberries
A brighter Statesmen. Very good. Still has a slight rye taste like OF but  finishes very nice and bright.
Smoke, sweet, vanilla, banana taffy.  Really enjoy it for it's uniqueness.
Noses of char and fruits. Smokey and smooth taste. Medium burn finish with charred hardwood notes.
Not as good as I was hoping, especially because I love the 1897 BIB

Nose is completely ripe bananas with a bit of a sour note.  Chocolate and coffee flavors come through on the backend of the palate; very reminiscent of Woodford Reserve Double Oaked.  The finish is fairly short, however has some decent spice that transitions back to that chocolate and banana aftertaste. This is certainly no 1920, but it’s not all that bad and an easy bourbon to sip and enjoy.

Incredible nose, sweet with banana and apple. A touch of brown sugar is also there just off the rim.
The taste is terrific. Apple and cherry come in right away, followed by banana. All of this is combined with a more present barrel near the end. The 93 proof gives a small spice, but the barrel is what’s really providing the spice element.
The palate carried over through the finish, sweet with the barrel shining through.
Lovely notes of banana pudding with vanilla wafers. Some ethanol on the finish. Best OF product out there for my tastes

Aroma - Vanilla Cream Cake, Toasted Oak and Cherry
Texture - Rich and Silky
Flavor - Honey and Cinnamon up front, melting into Vanilla, Chocolate and a subtle Expresso note
Finish - Long with Oak Char, Cinnamon

Aroma - Rich caramel and vanilla frosting roasting over sweet oak logs

Taste- Oak upfront lead into dark cherries and subtle milk chocolate

Finish - Smooth and heat free. Strong oak notes. Medium length finish.

I really enjoyed this one. Heavy on the bananas and a bit lighter on cherry with just the right amount of wood and heavy on the wood I must say. The flavors were extremely bold and very well balanced.

Dark dark color. Such sticky legs in the glass. Nose: Molasses’s syrup, deep rich oak, Brown sugar, cumin. Brown butter. Similar notes on palate. Smooth but a deep barrel spice makes an appearance. Finish is just nice syrup lingering syrupy flavors.
Still working on my palate to identify notes but in the meantime, I very much enjoy this.

Nose: Smokey vanilla
Neat: Vanilla and cinnamon 
Rocks: Maple and vanilla; opens up the sweetness quite a bit; sweet but smooth 

One of the better lower-middle proofs I’ve had

Color: Maple Syrup Brown
Nose: Charred Oak, vanilla, banana, and brown sugar
Palate: Classic Bourbon profile, vanilla, tannins, cinnamon, caramel, and burnt banana fosters
Finish: The spicy oak and cinnamon lingers long but the sweet Demerara sugars faded quickly
Overall: A great, quality Bourbon with good mouth feel, and classic notes. The one dimensional finish and concentration of wood notes, are the only reason why it is not higher.

Floral and herbal nose with slight medicinal tinge. More syrup and oil mouth feel than any other Old Forester, but retains dry finish. Lots of tea in the body with dark cherry and a slight rising burn to the finish, which has shades of absinthe. A unique experience, but not what I would rush back to.
Oak, vanilla, brown sugar, and maybe a hint of toasted marshmallow? Quite full and smooth.
The nose is lighter than mouth feel. Cigar, vanilla, and spice. It lingers. It’s wonderful.
Vanilla caramel baking spice. Like dessert!

Strong after burn, maple scent, Dark color, burnt flavor 

Better after waiting for ice to melt some
Vanilla and oak, little banana on the nose and palate. Strong oak on finish.
Finished it, but didn’t want to.

The hardest to find of the Whiskey Row series, I managed to pick one of these up in January just as they were opening a case. Because there are limited double maturation bourbon products on the market, I was very interested to try this in light of the Woodford Reserve Double Oaked store pick I got last year.

The nose is dense with oak sweetness: vanilla, brown sugar, buttery caramel, bread pudding, and cinnamon. Surprisingly I don't get any fruit notes. It smells higher than its proof, likely due to the strong oak influence. The cinnamon/bread pudding notes hit harder on the tongue. Of course the oak and rye spice are still present. It is really sweet, but very delicious. The finish is medium, and is not overtly tannic from the oak. I see some reviews mention a medicinal quality, I get none of that. This bourbon is defined by oak and sugar. For me it is the quintessential "dessert whiskey." I really enjoy one or two glasses, but after that the sweetness is overwhelming. 

This is a bourbon I could drink all day, and is sweet and drinkable enough to introduce friends to more complex and expensive bourbons. It is $2 less and better than Woodford Reserve Double Oaked, but much harder to find in NC. I like this a lot, but I personally wouldn't recommend going out of your way to buy this if you haven't tried the Woodford first. Try that, see if you like the profile, then look for this. I think Woodford was more bready and less sweet, and overall I think this has a more enjoyable profile. But that was a store pick so my opinion is muddled.
Massive and bold. oaky-vanilla. Some caramel sweetness. Touch of licorice. Great viscosity
This old forester to me was a much better expression than the 1920. I enjoyed the sample of this I tried
Decently sweet on the nose, surprisingly hot on initial sip, but calmed down after first sip. Not as flavorful as I hoped. Tasted at a friends place, probably wouldn’t buy myself
Classic bourbon flavor. Unique aftertaste that I honestly like. Reminds me of firework smoke in a good way. Buy it.
